div.p: I arrived here last Sunday morning, and at New York on Thursday. I wrote to you from Asheville on the Isthmus of Panama by the New Orleans Steamer, hoping that by those means you would get the letter much sooner than if I waited until arriving at New York.

Brother John came down from New Haven to see me. He is in good health and much improved in appearance. His final examination commenced on Saturday. He will not wait for the commencement but expects to go to Tennessee in two or three weeks.
I was at Mess Pouir for a day, and though I did not see him I heard that Andrew Jackson was doing well. I did not hear that Sister Mary had gone to Texas until I arrived in New York.

Although all I talked with on the subject speak in the highest terms of San Antonio, I do not much like the move, and fear Sister will not be content to live there. However she has a spirit to make her home happy, wherever she goes.

With the execption of a letter from Ma dated in August last and received on my arrival at Fort Vancouver in November, I have not had a letter from any member of the family since I left St. Louis, and while there I only had one from you. I really almost came to the conclusion that you had all cut my acquaintance. There is no news of importance here; opinion is divided as to whether there will be war or not. I have heard some distinguished men say they thought there would be war. Give my best love to ma, sister Rachel and all the family. Tell them to write to me, I hope you will write me a long letter, and say how things are going in Tennessee. I hope to hear that you have gotten over all you difficulties and are now doing well.
